4.1 Goodness-of-Fit Test These notes rely heavily upon PSU STAT 504 online notes. The chi-square goodness-of-fit test, tests whether observed frequency counts \(O_j\) of the \(j \in k\) levels of a categorical variable differ from expected frequency counts \(E_j\) (\(H_0\) is \(O_j = E_j, \hspace{5mm} \forall j \in k\). There are two test statistics for this test, \(X^2\) and \(G^2\). The sampling distribution of each test statistic approach the chi-squared distribution as \(n\) becomes large. Calculate both test statistic. If the resulting p-values are close, then you can be confident that the large-sample approximation is working well. The Pearson goodness-of-fit statistic is \[X^2 = \sum \frac{(O_j - E_j)^2}{E_j}\] where \(O_j = p_j n\) and \(E_j = \pi_j n\). The deviance statistic is \[G^2 = 2 \sum O_j \log \left( \frac{O_j}{E_j} \right)\] If the saturated model (the observed data represent the fit of the saturated model, the most complex model possible with the given data) proportions \(p_j\) equal equal the expected proportions \(\pi_j\),
